intro: Tragacantha cognata, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a flowering plant native to parts of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and woody, thorny stems. The plant produces a valuable gum resin, which has been used historically in various medicinal and industrial applications. Its leaves are trifoliate, and it typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, adapting to harsh climatic conditions. The plant plays an important ecological role in its native habitats by providing food and shelter for local wildlife.
